ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: You might not feel very confident talking about death yet—and that's completely okay.
ranges.action: Try joining a group or workshop where people talk openly about end-of-life topics. It's a great way to build comfort.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: You're about as comfortable talking about death as most people. That's a solid place to be.
ranges.action: Keep having open conversations when the opportunity comes up—it helps create a more supportive space for everyone.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You seem really comfortable talking about end-of-life matters, which is a real strength.
ranges.action: Use that comfort to gently support others who may find these conversations difficult. You can help make these talks feel safer.

ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: You may not have had much experience helping someone physically at the end of life. That's very common.
ranges.action: You could look into volunteering, or even just learn basic care skills—it can help build confidence over time.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: You've had some hands-on experience, about the same as most people.
ranges.action: Share what you've learned, and look for chances to build on your skills when you feel ready.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You've clearly had experience helping someone directly, and that's really valuable.
ranges.action: Consider mentoring others or getting involved in your community's end-of-life care efforts. Your experience can make a difference.

ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: You might not feel super confident supporting someone through dying yet, and that's totally normal.
ranges.action: Start small—maybe offer practical help to someone or learn more about what's involved in end-of-life care.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: You've got a solid base of experience, right in line with others.
ranges.action: Keep building on what you know, and don't hesitate to step in when you see someone needs support.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You've got strong practical knowledge. You know what to do and how to be there for someone.
ranges.action: Think about sharing what you know—others could really benefit from your experience.

ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: You may not have had many personal or professional experiences with death or dying.
ranges.action: Consider listening to others' stories, or gently reflect on your own feelings. That's a good starting point.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: Your experiences are about average—enough to give you a sense of what death and dying can be like.
ranges.action: Stay open to learning from your own experiences and those around you. It builds wisdom.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You've had more exposure to death and dying than most. That gives you valuable perspective.
ranges.action: You might find yourself naturally supporting others—your lived experience is a real asset.

ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: You might not feel very informed about end-of-life care or services right now.
ranges.action: Learning even just a bit more—like what options exist—can help you feel more prepared and confident.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: You've got a good, solid base of knowledge—enough to understand what's going on.
ranges.action: Keep asking questions and exploring. It'll help you and those you care about.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You know quite a lot about death-related matters. That's a powerful tool.
ranges.action: Consider helping others understand what you've learned—many people are looking for someone who can guide them.

ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: You might feel like your community doesn't offer much support around death and dying.
ranges.action: Think about ways you can connect with others—there may be more support out there than it seems.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: Your experience with community support is similar to most people's.
ranges.action: Look for ways to strengthen those ties—community can be a big help during difficult times.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You feel like your community is pretty supportive, which is wonderful.
ranges.action: Help keep that support going by getting involved and welcoming others in.

ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: It might feel like your community isn't very involved in end-of-life care.
ranges.action: You could explore local initiatives or even start conversations that help get more people engaged.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: Your community's involvement seems about average.
ranges.action: Keep encouraging participation—it helps everyone feel less alone.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You feel your community really steps up when it comes to end-of-life care.
ranges.action: You can help others feel confident joining in too—your example can inspire more engagement.

ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: You might not feel very supported by your community around death-related matters.
ranges.action: See if there are community groups or events that can help build that support. Small actions make a big difference.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: Your overall community score is similar to others'.
ranges.action: Keep showing up and being part of the conversation—it helps the whole community grow stronger.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You see your community as supportive and engaged around dying and grieving. That's a real strength.
ranges.action: Share what's working—others might be looking for ideas to build similar support in their own communities.

ranges.label: Lower
ranges.meaning: You may not feel very comfortable or knowledgeable about death yet, but that can change with time.
ranges.action: Start with one step—talk to someone, read something, or reflect on what death means to you. It all adds up.

ranges.label: Similar
ranges.meaning: You're in a similar place to most people—there's a good base, and room to grow.
ranges.action: Keep learning, talking, and staying open—it's a journey that grows with you.

ranges.label: Higher
ranges.meaning: You seem to have a strong level of comfort, knowledge, and experience. That's a real gift.
ranges.action: Think about how you can support others on their journey—you have a lot to offer.
